g.text: Ocean temperature impact on ice shelf extent
The recent thinning and retreat of Antarctic ice shelves has been attributed to both atmo-
sphere and ocean warming. However, the lack of continuous, multi-year direct observations
as well as limitations of climate and ice shelf models prevent a precise assessment on how
oating ice cap. Here we show
eastern Antarctic Peninsula has driven to major collapse and recession of the regional ice
shelf during both the instrumental period and the last 9000 years. Our projections following
the representative concentration pathway 8.5 emission scenario from the Fifth Assessment
Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change reveal a
temperature warming within the coming decades that will undoubtedly accelerate ice shelf
melting, including the southernmost sector of the eastern Antarctic Peninsula.
Instituto Andaluz de Ciencias de la Tierra, CSIC-Universidad Granada, 18100 Armilla (Granada), Spain.
NIOZ Royal Netherlands Institute for Sea Research, Utrecht University, 1790 Texel, The Netherlands.
Cooperation Unit, Alfred Wegener Institute, 27570 Bremerhaven, Germany.
Instituto de Investigaciones Oceanologicas, Universidad Autónoma de Baja

of Geosciences, University of Utrecht, 3584 Utrecht, The Netherlands.
Earth and Life Institute, Université de Louvain, 1348 Louvain-la-Neuve, Belgium.
UMI CNRS Takuvik, Université de Laval, G1V0A6 Québec, QC, Canada.
Korea Polar Research Institute, 21990 Incheon, South Korea. Correspondence and
requests for materials should be addressed to J.E. (email: johan.etourneau@iact.ugr-csic.es)
